content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment, in which the following events occur.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A slides to the right along a horizontal surface toward identical block B, which is at rest.

At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides with and sticks to block B.

At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A and block B are still stuck together and the right side of block B reaches an ideal, horizontal spring with negligible mass and spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spring is initially at its relaxed (uncompressed) length and fixed to a wall.

At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the spring is compressed a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the blocks are instantaneously at rest.

Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface.

A student observes the experiment and makes the following claim.

"Since some mechanical energy is dissipated when the blocks stick together, the momentum of the two-block system decreases."

(a) Indicate whether the claim is correct or incorrect and explain why.

frqParts.text:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment, in which the following events occur.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A slides to the right along a horizontal surface toward identical block B, which is at rest.

At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides with and sticks to block B.

At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A and block B are still stuck together and the right side of block B reaches an ideal, horizontal spring with negligible mass and spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spring is initially at its relaxed (uncompressed) length and fixed to a wall.

At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the spring is compressed a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the blocks are instantaneously at rest.

Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface.

A student observes the experiment and makes the following claim.

"Since some mechanical energy is dissipated when the blocks stick together, the momentum of the two-block system decreases."

(a) Indicate whether the claim is correct or incorrect and explain why.

Another student makes the following claim about the collision between block A and block B.
"When the blocks collide the total momentum of the two-block system doesn't change, so the kinetic energy of the system must also be constant."
(b) Indicate whether the claim is correct or incorrect and explain why.

(c) During the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is the magnitude of the acceleration of the two-block system increasing, decreasing, or constant? Briefly explain why.

(d) During the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, does the spring do positive, negative, or zero work on the two-block system? Briefly explain your answer.

In Case 2 shown above, the setup is identical to Case 1 except that a stiffer spring is used. The spring in Case 2 has a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that is greater than <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Block A slides with the same speed as in Case 1 and the spring compresses a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) How does the new maximum spring compression distance <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in Case 2 compare to <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in Case 1? (Is <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the same as <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, or less than <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?)
(f) Briefly explain your reasoning for part (e).

Students attempt to determine a general equation for the maximum compression distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a spring with spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Block A has mass <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and initial speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and block B has mass <math alttext="m sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students come up with the following two equations.

Equation 1: <math alttext="d equals, the fraction with numerator C sub 1, end sub, times m sub A, end sub, times v, and denominator the square root of, k times, open parenthesis, m sub A, end sub, plus m sub B, close parenthesis, end root, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> Equation 2: <math alttext="d equals, C sub 2, end sub, times, open parenthesis, k times the square root of, m sub A, end sub, plus m sub B, end root, close parenthesis, times v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><msqrt><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

In the two equations, <math alttext="c sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="c sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive constants with appropriate units.

(g) Without algebraic manipulation of equations or deriving the correct equation, explain which equation better supports your explanation for the compression distance in part (f).

(h) The graph above shows the displacement of the blocks while block B is in contact with the spring. The solid line corresponds to either Case 1 or Case 2, while the dashed line corresponds to the other case. Does the solid-line curve correspond to Case 1 (with a smaller spring constant) or Case 2 (with a larger spring constant)? Explain your reasoning.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
